title-group.article-title: Latent profile analysis of empathy for pain and its associations with coping styles among nurses in China

contrib-group.aff: 2Dongguan Eighth People’s Hospital, Dongguan, Guangdong, China
3Endocrinology Department, Dongguan Eighth People’s Hospital, Dongguan, Guangdong, China

fn.p: BL, YH and QL are joint first authors.
BL, YH and QL contributed equally.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: This study sought to evaluate the prevalence of empathy for pain among nurses in Chinese hospitals through latent profile analysis, identify latent subgroups and their demographic characteristics and examine the relationship between different subgroups and coping styles.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: A multicentre cross-sectional study.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: The study was conducted in 43 hospitals across Guangdong Province, China, comprising 36 general medical hospitals and 7 specialty hospitals.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: This study recruited 1656 registered nurses with over 1 year of clinical experience from 43 hospitals in Guangdong Province, China, using a convenience sampling method between June and September 2023. A total of 1601 valid questionnaires were returned, with a response rate of 96.68%.

sec.title: Primary and secondary outcome measures
sec.p: Data were collected through online questionnaires using the General Information Questionnaire, the Chinese Version of the Empathy for Pain Scale and the Simplified Coping Style Questionnaire. Latent profile analysis was applied to assess the characteristics of nurses’ empathy for pain, while logistic regression analysis was employed to identify factors influencing the different empathy for pain profiles.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The mean empathy for pain score among the 1601 clinical nurses was 2.92±0.79. Nurses’ empathy for pain was categorised into three latent profiles: low empathy sensitivity (33.9%), balanced response (48%) and empathy contradiction (18.1%). Univariate analysis demonstrated significant variations in the distribution of nurses across different profiles concerning age, marital status, childbearing status, perceived pain tolerance, job satisfaction, participation in pain-related knowledge training, designation as a pain resource nurse and coping styles scores. Logistic regression analysis identified perceived pain tolerance, job satisfaction and coping styles as significant determinants of nurses’ latent empathy for pain profiles (p<0.05).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Nurses’ empathy for pain characteristics exhibits heterogeneity and can be categorised into three latent profiles. Nursing managers should implement targeted interventions tailored to each profile, focusing on the key determinants such as perceived pain tolerance, job satisfaction and coping styles. These interventions can enhance nurses’ empathy for pain, promote the adoption of positive coping styles and ultimately improve clinical pain management and overall nursing care quality.

caption.title: Strengths and limitations of this study

list-item.p: This study employed latent profile analysis to explore the heterogeneity of empathy for pain among nurses in Guangdong Province, China, which provides valuable insights for targeted interventions.
The study involved a large sample of nurses from 43 hospitals, contributing to the robustness of the findings and their applicability to diverse healthcare settings.
The study is limited by its cross-sectional design, which does not allow for the establishment of causal relationships between empathy for pain and influencing factors.
This study is limited by its use of convenience sampling.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pain is a globally prevalent health issue and is often regarded as the ‘fifth vital sign’.1 It has garnered significant attention and emerged as a focal point of research. In the USA, approximately 20% of adults experience chronic pain,2 imposing substantial personal and economic burdens.3 Beyond physical distress, chronic pain can contribute to mental health disorders, including anxiety and depression, thereby further diminishing patients’ quality of life.4 Therefore, effective pain management is crucial for enhancing patients’ overall well-being.

Pain is frequently overlooked as a subjective symptom,5 particularly when contrasted with more visibly evident conditions such as severe trauma or disability, potentially resulting in delays or inadequacies in its management. Although effective pain management necessitates a multidisciplinary approach, nurses occupy a pivotal role in hospital settings, serving as primary assessors of patients’ pain, implementers of analgesic interventions and educators in pain management.6 Empathy, in particular, is essential to pain assessment—a process deeply rooted in subjective judgement and interpersonal communication. It facilitates a more accurate interpretation of patients’ pain expressions by nurses, thereby bridging the discrepancy between patients’ subjective pain experiences and clinicians’ assessments. Such alignment contributes to more precise and individualised pain evaluation.7 Specifically, recognising non-verbal indicators of patient distress—such as facial expressions, subtle changes in vocal tone and behavioural responses—is a critical empathic behaviour required of nurses during pain assessment.8 Therefore, empathy plays a pivotal role in pain assessment. As a specific manifestation of empathy in pain management, empathy for pain not only directly influences patients’ pain outcomes but also contributes positively to the long-term improvement of care quality and the advancement of professional nursing practice.9 10

Empathy is the capacity to comprehend and resonate with another individual’s situation and emotions from their perspective.11 It is a fundamental professional attribute in healthcare and a crucial component of high-quality care delivery.12 Empathy for pain, a distinct subset of empathy, encompasses an individual’s perception, evaluation and emotional reaction to another’s pain.13 A high degree of empathy for pain in clinical settings is linked to improved patient outcomes. It enhances treatment satisfaction and adherence, mitigates anxiety and alleviates pain.14 15 For nurses, well-developed empathy for pain skills strengthen their ability to discern patients’ priorities and collect comprehensive pain-related information.16 This facilitates precise pain assessment and effective interventions, thereby fostering confidence, accountability and professional fulfilment among nurses in clinical practice. Conversely, inadequate empathy for pain may result in diminished sensitivity to patients’ pain, contributing to suboptimal pain management, underestimation of pain severity and incomplete clinical documentation.17 However, excessive empathy for pain may also have detrimental consequences, including emotional exhaustion, burnout and heightened psychological distress.18 19

It is important to note that there are substantial individual differences in nurses’ levels of empathy for pain. According to previous studies, these variations may be closely associated with demographic factors such as gender, age, marital status and childbearing status, as well as pain-related knowledge, professional experience and personal pain history. For instance, nurses aged 30 and above, those who are married, have children or work a moderate number of hours per week tend to exhibit higher levels of empathy for pain.20 21 This may be related to greater levels of social support, a stronger sense of responsibility and more effective family communication. Moderate working hours may also help maintain a healthy work–life balance and psychological well-being. Nurses who have received training in pain-related knowledge tend to demonstrate higher levels of empathy for pain, as they possess more specialised knowledge and skills, enabling them to more effectively recognise patients’ emotional needs and pain experiences.6 Therefore, nurses’ individual characteristics shape their empathy for pain and influence various aspects of pain management, especially during assessment, thereby affecting the overall quality of pain care.22

According to Goubert’s theory, witnessing another individual’s pain evokes an emotional response, which subsequently triggers a corresponding behavioural reaction.23 Empathy for pain influences not only nurses’ emotional responses but also their coping styles. Coping styles encompass deliberate psychological and behavioural responses to stress or adversity and are typically classified into active and passive coping mechanisms.24 Active coping encompasses strategies such as seeking support and problem-solving, whereas passive coping involves emotional avoidance and negative affective expression.25 Previous studies have shown that individuals with higher levels of empathy are more likely to adopt positive coping styles and are more inclined to seek social support.26 Among nurses, varying levels of empathy for pain may be associated with different coping styles. However, research on this relationship remains limited.

In recent years, research on empathy for pain has deepened globally. The focus has progressively expanded from early investigations of neural mechanisms and physician populations to broader clinical roles, including nurses and patients. The research perspective has also shifted from predominantly theoretical explorations of psychological mechanisms to the examination of empathic behaviours and functions within real-world clinical interactions.22 As a typical manifestation of empathy in clinical nursing, empathy for pain has received increasing attention for its clinical value. However, existing global research on nurses’ empathy for pain still presents several limitations. On the one hand, studies employing latent profile analysis (LPA) to identify and examine distinct profiles of empathy for pain among nurses remain limited. Most existing research has focused on linear associations between isolated factors and has predominantly relied on scale-based assessments. These approaches frequently overlook individual variability and fail to encapsulate the heterogeneous manifestations of empathy for pain. On the other hand, behavioural differences in coping styles across different types of empathy for pain have not yet been clearly defined. This lack of clarity hinders the systematic understanding of individual differences in nurses’ empathy for pain and limits deeper insight into their corresponding coping styles and behavioural expressions, thereby constraining the development of more targeted clinical intervention strategies.

To address the limitations of existing research, LPA offers a novel perspective for investigation. LPA, a person-centred statistical approach, enables the identification of unobserved heterogeneity within a population. It allows for the classification of latent subgroups of nurses based on their empathy for pain and supports further exploration of how sociodemographic characteristics and coping styles may relate to these subgroups. This method helps reveal previously unrecognised profiles of empathy for pain within the nursing population and sheds light on behavioural differences in coping styles across subgroups. LPA may offer new empirical possibilities for better understanding the heterogeneity in nurses’ empathy for pain and their corresponding coping styles.27 28 Therefore, this study aims to assess the current status of empathy for pain among clinical nurses in China and to identify latent profiles through LPA. It also aims to analyse subgroup characteristics and explore the associations between different empathy for pain profiles and coping styles, with the goal of informing precision management and individualised interventions for empathy for pain in clinical nursing practice.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This study employed an analytical cross-sectional design and followed the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology guidelines to enhance the reporting of observational findings.

sec.title: Sample size estimation
sec.p: This study used G*Power V.3.1 to estimate the required sample size based on multiple regression analysis. Referring to previous studies on factors influencing nurses’ empathy for pain,14 15 the effect size was set at 0.10, with a statistical power of 0.95 and a significance level (α) of 0.05. A total of 21 independent variables were included, comprising 17 items from the General Demographic Information Questionnaire and two dimensions each from the Chinese Version of the Empathy for Pain Scale (EPS-C) and the Simplified Coping Style Questionnaire (SCSQ). The calculation indicated a minimum required sample size of 330 participants. Considering an expected 20% rate of invalid questionnaires and following the recommendation by Nylund-Gibson and Choi that LPA requires no fewer than 500 cases,29 the final minimum sample size for this study was set at 500.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: This study employed a multicentre cross-sectional design. Data were collected between June and September 2023 through a convenience sampling approach, encompassing 1601 clinical nurses from 43 hospitals across Guangdong Province, including 36 general hospitals and 7 specialised hospitals. Participants were drawn from diverse clinical departments, including inpatient wards, outpatient clinics, emergency units, intensive care units and operating theatres. The inclusion criteria were defined as follows: (1) Age between 18 and 60 years, in accordance with the Regulations of the People’s Republic of China on Nurses, the legal age of majority, and the statutory retirement age in China. (2) Registered nurses actively involved in clinical practice. (3) A minimum of 1 year of clinical nursing experience, based on evidence indicating that nurses with less than 1 year of experience often exhibit unstable responses in empathy for pain and coping styles due to limited clinical exposure and high levels of adaptation-related stress.30 31 (4) Provided informed consent and voluntarily participated in the study. The exclusion criteria included: (1) Nurses enrolled in external training programmes. (2) Nurses on prolonged leave. (3) Intern nurses or rehired personnel.

sec.title: General demographic information
sec.p: The questionnaire was developed by the research team based on a review of the literature related to nurses’ empathy for pain6 21 32 and consultations with clinical nursing experts. The questionnaire included items covering sociodemographic characteristics (gender, age, educational attainment, only-child status, marital status and childbearing status) and clinical and professional characteristics (professional title, years of clinical experience, department, weekly working hours, exposure to workplace violence, history of major trauma or severe pain, experience with chronic pain, perceived pain tolerance, job satisfaction, participation in pain empathy training and designation as a pain resource nurse).

sec.title: Chinese version of the Empathy for Pain Scale
sec.p: The EPS-C was originally developed by Giummarra in 2014,13 translated and adapted by Shang Jing in 2020, and subsequently validated among Chinese medical students.33 The EPS-C comprises two dimensions: bodily and mental discomfort reactions and empathic reactions. The bodily and mental discomfort reactions refer to the psychological or physiological distress an individual experiences when vicariously perceiving another person’s pain. The empathic reactions encompass psychological responses such as discomfort, sympathy and the urge to intervene or offer assistance when recognising another person’s pain. The scale presents four distinct pain scenarios: intraoperative, postoperative, physical assault and accidental injury. Each scenario comprises 12 identical items, resulting in a total of 48 items. A 5-point Likert scale was employed, ranging from 1 (‘strongly disagree’) to 5 (‘strongly agree’). The mean score for each item across the four scenarios was computed as the item score. The dimension score was obtained by averaging the item scores within that dimension, while the total score was derived from the mean of all item scores. Higher scores reflect greater empathy for pain. A score of ≥3 denotes a high level of empathy for pain, whereas a score of <3 signifies a low level. The Cronbach’s α coefficient for the original scale was 0.914, while in this study, it reached 0.975, demonstrating excellent internal consistency.

sec.title: Simplified Coping Style Questionnaire
sec.p: This study employed the SCSQ, originally developed by Xie.34 The SCSQ comprises two dimensions: positive coping and negative coping. It contains 20 items that assess various coping styles and attitudes individuals may employ in daily life. Items 1–12 measure positive coping styles, whereas items 13–20 evaluate negative coping styles. Responses are rated on a 4-point Likert scale, ranging from 0 (‘never use’) to 3 (‘frequently use’). The mean scores for positive and negative coping styles were computed separately. Higher mean scores indicate a greater tendency to adopt the corresponding coping styles. The SCSQ has been validated among nurses, demonstrating robust reliability and validity.35 The Cronbach’s α coefficient for the scale in the present study was 0.919.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Data for this study were collected online using the Questionnaire Star platform (http://www.wjx.cn). The principal investigator first contacted the head nurse of each hospital’s nursing department to provide a comprehensive explanation of the study’s objectives, target participants and questionnaire completion process. To minimise selection bias associated with convenience sampling, unified training was conducted for the nursing department heads and research staff at all participating hospitals prior to questionnaire distribution. This training aimed to ensure consistency in the dissemination and implementation procedures. Additionally, all participating hospitals strictly adhered to standardised inclusion and exclusion criteria to ensure uniformity and comparability in participant selection. On receiving approval, the questionnaire link and QR code were disseminated through the WeChat platform to nursing departments, which subsequently distributed them to nurses in their respective hospitals. Prior to completing the questionnaire, participants were presented with an informed consent statement detailing the study’s objectives, significance, and participation guidelines, along with the researcher’s contact information. The statement assured participants of anonymity and confidentiality and informed them of their right to withdraw at any time. It also emphasised that all data would be used solely for research purposes by the study team. On agreeing to the consent statement, participants could proceed with the questionnaire. To ensure data completeness, participants were required to address any missing responses before submission. Moreover, each account was restricted to a single submission to prevent duplicate entries. Two research team members continuously monitored the Questionnaire Star platform to oversee data collection. Once no new responses were recorded for a week, the dataset was exported. Researchers then conducted a meticulous review of each questionnaire, excluding those completed in an implausibly short time or exhibiting logical inconsistencies to ensure data integrity.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: LPA was performed using Mplus V.8.3 to examine nurses’ empathy for pain.36 Models with one to five profiles were sequentially analysed, and the final model fit was evaluated using three key indices: (1) Model fit was evaluated based on the Akaike information criterion (AIC), Bayesian information criterion (BIC) and adjusted BIC (aBIC), which measure discrepancies between expected and observed values. Lower values indicate superior model fit. (2) Classification accuracy was assessed using entropy, which ranges from 0 to 1, with values closer to 1 indicating higher classification precision. (3) Model fit was compared between k-1 and k profiles using the Lo-Mendell-Rubin (LMR) test and the bootstrap likelihood ratio test. A p<0.05 for both tests indicates that the k-profile model provides a significantly better fit than the k-1 profile model. These indices provide a statistical basis for profile selection; however, the interpretability of each profile must also be considered when determining the optimal model.37 38

Data analyses were conducted using SPSS V.27.0 statistical software.39 Harman’s one-factor test was used to assess common method bias. Continuous variables were presented as mean±SD, and group comparisons were performed using the t-test or analysis of variance. Categorical variables were summarised as frequencies and percentages, with group comparisons conducted using the χ2 test or rank-sum test. Based on the results of univariate analyses, a multinomial logistic regression model was constructed to further explore the influencing factors of nurses’ latent profiles of empathy for pain. The three identified empathy for pain profiles were used as the dependent variable, and variables found to be statistically significant in the univariate analyses were included as independent variables. ORs and 95% CIs were reported. The significance level was set at α=0.05. All tests were two-tailed, and p values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: Patients and the public were not involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination of this study.

sec.title: Common method bias test
sec.p: This study relied on a self-report questionnaire for data collection, which may be susceptible to common method bias. To evaluate this potential bias, Harman’s one-factor test was performed. Exploratory factor analysis of the questionnaire items indicated that the first common factor accounted for 28.78% of the variance, remaining below the 40% threshold for significant common variance.40 These findings suggest the absence of substantial common method bias in this study.

sec.title: General demographic information
sec.p: A total of 1656 questionnaires were collected in this study, of which 1601 were deemed valid, yielding an effective response rate of 96.68%. Among the 55 invalid questionnaires, 33 were excluded due to incorrect information on years of clinical experience, and 22 were excluded due to logical inconsistencies in demographic information. Among the included participants, the majority were female (n=1561, 97.5%), and 74.7% were under 40 years old. Approximately 59% held a bachelor’s degree or higher, while 72.3% held the title of nurse or supervisor nurse. Additionally, 57.4% had over 10 years of clinical experience, and 78.9% worked more than 40 hours per week. Only 23.7% of nurses had received pain empathy training, and 6.8% were designated as pain resource nurses. Furthermore, 25.7% and 21.6% of participants reported exposure to workplace violence and a history of major trauma or severe pain, respectively. Further details are presented in tables12.

caption.title: Sociodemographic characteristics of nurses and univariate analysis of latent profiles of empathy for pain (n=1601)
Clinical and professional characteristics of nurses and univariate analysis of latent profiles of empathy for pain (n=1601)

tr.td: History of major trauma or severe pain
Designation as a pain resource nurse

fn.p: ‘Other departments’ in this study refer to clinical units not individually categorised under the main department classifications. These primarily include anaesthesiology, traditional Chinese medicine, rehabilitation, infectious diseases, dialysis and psychiatry. Due to the heterogeneous nature of these departments and the relatively small number of nurses in each, they were combined into a single category labelled ‘other departments’.

sec.title: Latent profiling of the empathy for pain in nurses
sec.p: To determine the optimal model, five candidate models were evaluated in this study. Table 3 reports the fit statistics for each model. Although the profile 2 model exhibited the highest entropy value (0.982), the profile 3 model demonstrated a consistent decline in AIC, BIC and aBIC values before reaching stability. The LMR p values for the profile 4 and profile 5 models did not reach statistical significance. Table 4 presents the probability matrices for nurse classification into the three latent profiles, with classification probabilities ranging from 98% to 99%, suggesting high model reliability. Considering the model proportions and the practical relevance of the results, the profile 3 model was selected as the most appropriate. Table 5 illustrates the distribution of empathy for pain dimensions across the three latent profiles, with all differences reaching statistical significance. Figure 1 visualises the scores of the three latent profiles across the 12 observed indicators.

caption.title: The distribution of latent profile scores for empathy for pain across three latent profiles identified in nurses. Profile 1 (low empathy sensitivity, 33.9%), Profile 2 (balanced response, 48%) and profile 3 (empathy contradiction, 18.1%) are each represented by distinct lines. The scores correspond to items of the EPS scale, where empathy reactions are represented by items 1 and 9–10, and body and mind discomfort reactions are represented by items 2–8 and 11–12. The y-axis represents the mean value of item scores (points), while the x-axis indicates the items of the EPS Scale. EPS, Empathy for Pain Scale.
Fitting statistic for a latent profile model of the empathy for pain in nurses (n=1601)

fn.p: aBIC, adjusted BIC; AIC, Akaike information criteria; BIC, Bayesian information criteria; BLRT, bootstrapped likelihood ratio test; LMR, Lo-Mendell-Rubin Test.

caption.title: Categorical probability matrix of the empathy for pain in nurses across the three latent profiles (percentage, %)

fn.p: Rows represent individuals from different profiles, and columns represent the average probability of assignment to each profile.

caption.title: Comparison of empathy for pain scores across three latent profiles in nurses (n=1601, X¯±S)

sec.p: Based on item-level scores reflecting distinct latent characteristics, nurses were categorised into three groups: profile 1, profile 2 and profile 3. Profile 1 accounted for 33.9% of the total sample (n=543), making it the second-largest group. Nurses in this group had the lowest scores on both the bodily and mental discomfort reactions and empathic reactions dimensions, indicating relatively low sensitivity to empathy for pain. These nurses appeared to maintain emotional detachment from their patients during interactions. Therefore, this group was designated as the ‘low empathy sensitivity’ group. Profile 2, the largest group, comprised 48% of the total sample (n=768). Nurses in this group had moderate scores on both the bodily and mental discomfort reactions and empathic reactions dimensions, suggesting that they experienced a moderate level of empathy for pain along with physical and psychological discomfort when encountering patient pain. This response pattern reflects a relatively balanced emotional response. Thus, this group was designated as the ‘balanced response’ group. Profile 3 comprised 18.1% of the total sample (n=290). These nurses exhibited a generally high capacity for empathy for pain; however, their scores on ‘compassion’ (item 9) and ‘willingness to help’ (item 10) were relatively low. This finding suggests that, despite their strong emotional empathy for patients’ pain, their motivation to assist was somewhat restrained. Additionally, nurses in this group had the highest scores on the bodily and mental discomfort reactions dimension, suggesting that while they experienced intense emotional empathy for their patients’ pain, they also endured considerable physical and psychological distress. Consequently, this group was designated as the ‘empathy contradiction’ group.

sec.title: Univariate analysis of the latent profiles of empathy for pain in nurses
sec.p: Tables1 6 present the comparative analysis of general demographic characteristics and coping styles across the three latent profiles. Univariate analyses identified significant differences (p<0.05) among the three nurse profiles concerning age, marital status, childbearing status, perceived pain tolerance, job satisfaction, pain-related knowledge training, designation as a pain resource nurse and scores for both positive and negative coping styles.

caption.title: Comparison of simplified coping style questionnaire scores across latent profiles in nurses (n=1601, X¯±S)

sec.title: Multivariate analysis of the latent profiles of empathy for pain in nurses
sec.p: Statistically significant factors from the univariate analyses, along with the dimensions of simplified coping styles, were included as independent variables. The three latent profiles of empathy for pain were set as the dependent variable in the multinomial logistic regression analysis. The dependent variable was coded as follows: low empathy sensitivity=1, balanced response=2 and empathy contradiction=3. The independent variables were coded as follows: age: 18-29 =(1,0,0), 30-39=(0,1,0), ≥40=(0,0,0). Marital status: single=(1,0,0), married=(0,1,0), divorced/widowed=(0,0,0). Childbearing status: yes=1, no=2. Perceived pain tolerance: poor=(1,0,0), average=(0,1,0), good=(0,0,0). Job satisfaction: dissatisfied=(1,0,0), neutral=(0,1,0), satisfied=(0,0,0). pain empathy training: yes=1, no=2. Pain resource nurse: yes=1, no=2; positive and negative coping style scores were included as continuous variables. The logistic regression results indicated that perceived pain tolerance, job satisfaction and coping styles were significant predictors of nurses’ latent empathy for pain profiles (p<0.05). Compared with the low empathy sensitivity group, nurses with lower perceived pain tolerance were more likely to be classified into the balanced response group (OR=1.476, 95% CI: 1.044 to 2.088; OR=1.434, 95% CI: 1.104 to 1.862). Nurses with moderate levels of job satisfaction were also more likely to belong to the balanced response group (OR=1.321, 95% CI: 1.019 to 1.711). In terms of coping styles, higher scores on negative coping were associated with a greater likelihood of being classified into the empathy contradiction group (OR=1.312, 95% CI: 1.259 to 1.367, p<0.001). Details are presented in table 7.

caption.title: Multivariate analysis of the latent profiles of empathy for pain in nurses

Profile 3 vs profile 1 (profile 1 as a reference）
Profile 2 vs profile 3 (profile 3 as a reference）

fn.p: SCSQ, Simplified Coping Style Questionnaire; β, beta coefficient.

sec.title: Current status of empathy for pain among clinical nurses
sec.p: The study results indicated that the empathy for pain scale score among 1601 clinical nurses was 2.92±0.79, slightly exceeding the national norm.33 Overall, this score reflects a moderate level of empathy, aligning with findings from previous studies.6 This trend may be attributed to the nationwide implementation of quality nursing services in China since 2011. This initiative seeks to improve nurses’ fundamental competencies by emphasising patient-centred care. Empathy is a fundamental driver of patient-centred care.41 Consequently, nurses have become more attuned to patients’ psychological states and increasingly sensitive to their emotional experiences. Additionally, the empathy reactions dimension had a higher score (3.56±0.74) compared with the national norm (2.23±0.73). In contrast, the score for the bodily and mental discomfort reactions dimension (2.70±0.89) was lower than the national norm (3.39±0.77). These findings indicate that clinical nurses effectively empathise with patients’ suffering, exhibiting a strong empathic response despite experiencing moderate physical and psychological discomfort. This emotional response pattern promotes pro-social behaviours, such as empathy and caregiving, thereby strengthening nurse–patient relationships and optimising pain management.

Conversely, the prevalence of low empathy for pain among nurses was 52.53% (841/1601), based on a threshold score of less than 3 on the EPS. This finding suggests that nearly half of the nurses in this study exhibited low levels of empathy for pain, highlighting substantial room for improvement. Several factors may contribute to this phenomenon. Clinical nurses in hospital settings frequently experience high workloads and are responsible for managing complex cases while attending to multiple patients simultaneously. This imposes considerable psychological stress and emotional strain on nurses, limiting their time and capacity to attend to patients’ pain experiences. As a result, their ability to effectively empathise with patients’ suffering is hindered. Furthermore, many hospitalised patients suffer from severe medical conditions, and some may be unconscious or cognitively impaired, complicating communication with nurses and limiting their engagement in treatment plans. As a result, nurses may underestimate the severity of patients’ pain, overlook the need for pain relief and consequently experience a diminished capacity to empathise with patients’ pain.9 Additionally, the psychological burden associated with the COVID-19 pandemic further exacerbated the decline in nurses’ empathy for pain levels.18

This study further revealed that only 23.7% of clinical nurses had received training in pain empathy knowledge, and merely 6.8% had been designated as pain resource nurses, underscoring a widespread deficiency in pain management knowledge among nurses. Undergraduate nursing education serves as the cornerstone of nurses’ knowledge base and subsequent clinical practice. However, the scope and comprehensiveness of pain management education in nursing curricula remain insufficient. Additionally, the time dedicated to pain education is insufficient, and the content is frequently fragmented within nursing curricula.42 Therefore, enhancing empathy skills among front-line clinical nurses is essential for improving the patient care experience. Evidence suggests that empathy is a trainable skill.43 Nursing managers should evaluate nurses’ empathy for pain in clinical settings and prioritise initiatives aimed at developing and strengthening this skill. For instance, incorporating high-fidelity simulations and scenario-based training into pain management education enables nurses to engage with patient pain in realistic clinical contexts. This approach facilitates the integration of theoretical knowledge with clinical practice, ultimately optimising pain management outcomes in patient care.44 45

sec.title: Latent profiles of empathy for pain in clinical nurses
sec.p: This study employed LPA to identify three distinct latent profiles of empathy for pain among nurses: low empathy sensitivity, balanced response and empathy contradiction. Significant differences were observed in both the total and dimensional scores of empathy for pain across the profiles, underscoring the heterogeneity in nurses’ empathic responses to pain. Furthermore, significant differences in positive and negative coping style scores were observed among the latent profiles, partially validating the distinctiveness of the identified empathy for pain profiles.

The low empathy sensitivity group accounted for 33.9% of the sample, with nurses in this profile exhibiting the lowest empathy for pain scores relative to the overall average. This pattern may be associated with younger age, unmarried status and lack of childcare experience among these nurses. Newly recruited young nurses often have limited clinical experience, which may hinder their ability to effectively manage complex clinical tasks and assessments. Additionally, younger nurses may encounter greater professional competition and are less likely to benefit from the nuclear family support associated with marriage, potentially further contributing to their lower levels of empathy for pain.

The balanced response group accounted for 48% of the sample, representing the predominant profile of empathy for pain among nurses. Nurses in this group generally possessed extensive professional experience. Previous studies have shown that nurses with extensive professional and life experience exhibit greater sensitivity to patients’ behaviours and emotions and are more likely to engage in altruistic behaviours.46 Moreover, a stable marital status offers crucial psychological support, fostering emotional stability and overall well-being, which allows nurses to devote more attention to assessing and managing patients’ pain symptoms.47 Nurses with children may develop heightened empathy for patients’ pain, as parental caregiving instincts tend to be more pronounced, enhancing their sensitivity to patients’ pain-related needs. Consequently, married nurses with children may employ more sophisticated emotional coping styles to navigate family responsibilities alongside professional demands, allowing them to empathise with patients while preserving their own emotional well-being.

The empathy contradiction group accounted for 18.1% of the sample, representing the smallest proportion of nurses exhibiting empathy for pain, yet it was distinguished by unique characteristics. Previous research indicates that greater intrinsic motivation, such as a willingness to help others, is positively associated with higher empathy levels in nursing students.48 Compared with the other profiles, nurses in this category exhibited a high level of empathy for patients’ pain but displayed greater reservation in their motivation to help. This phenomenon may stem from the fact that nurses in this group endure significant physical and psychological discomfort while exhibiting heightened empathy for pain. Most nurses in this category are over 30 years old and possess extensive experience in patient management and pain care. Their deep understanding of patients’ pain conditions and clinical decision-making enables them to draw on personal experience and altruistic motivation, fostering a heightened level of empathy for pain. However, beyond fulfilling management-assigned duties, these experienced nurses frequently mentor junior staff and nursing students. Combined with the demands of their daily clinical workload, this increased responsibility may heighten their susceptibility to physical and psychological distress when confronted with patients’ pain or injuries.46 Previous studies have also demonstrated that healthcare workers are particularly vulnerable to physical discomfort, such as tingling, throbbing or gastrointestinal distress, when observing patients’ pain and recalling their own past pain experiences, particularly under repeated exposure to diverse pain-related situations. This phenomenon may ultimately contribute to compassion fatigue and reduced work efficiency.49 More concerningly, as nurses engage with a greater number of patients, their heightened sensitivity to others’ pain may lead them to internalise patients’ pain as their own.50 Therefore, nursing managers should acknowledge the significance of empathy reactions to pain while remaining cognisant of the adverse effects of bodily and mental discomfort reactions associated with empathy for pain. Additionally, it is crucial to prevent nurses from sustaining heightened empathy states for prolonged periods, as this may ultimately impair their capacity for effective empathy.

Moreover, the majority of nurses in this group were designated pain resource nurses who had undergone pain-related training. Studies indicate that nurses with adequate pain-related knowledge and a positive attitude play a crucial role in effective pain management.51 52 Empathy training has been recognised as an effective approach to enhancing nurses’ empathy for pain.6 Clinical nurses who have undergone pain-related training tend to demonstrate higher levels of empathy for pain. This is because structured and comprehensive pain education not only equips nurses with strong professional knowledge but also enhances their humanistic qualities and specialised pain management skills, fostering greater sensitivity to the emotional and psychological changes patients experience during pain. In clinical pain management, pain resource nurses are more likely to exhibit proactive engagement and heightened empathy. They uphold a positive attitude towards pain management and tend to display stronger empathic responses.53 Although healthcare professionals with high empathy levels excel in patient care and understanding, they are also more susceptible to psychological stressors, including compassion fatigue and burnout.54 Empathy functions as a double-edged sword. Research based on the multidimensional empathy model suggests that cognitive empathy contributes to empathy satisfaction. However, excessive empathy can result in personal distress, exacerbate burnout and compassion fatigue, and diminish professional fulfilment.50 Therefore, this group requires special consideration. Nurses must maintain a balance between emotional engagement and rational detachment, enabling them to provide compassionate care while mitigating excessive emotional involvement. Achieving this balance can improve nurses’ ability to manage their work effectively and enhance their overall professional well-being.

sec.title: Factors influencing latent profiles of empathy for pain
sec.p: This study identified perceived pain tolerance as a significant determinant in classifying nurses’ empathy for pain profiles. Nurses with lower perceived pain tolerance were more likely to be classified into the balanced response group rather than the low empathy sensitivity group. This finding aligns with previous research, which suggests that nurses with lower perceived pain tolerance are generally more sensitive to pain, more likely to exhibit empathic responses when witnessing others’ physical or psychological pain, and tend to demonstrate higher levels of affective resonance.32 This phenomenon may be related to the neural processing involved when individuals observe others in pain. Individuals with higher empathy tend to exhibit stronger activation in the anterior cingulate cortex and insula when witnessing others’ suffering.55 Therefore, those with lower perceived pain tolerance may be more likely to activate empathy-related brain regions at the neural level, which could contribute to higher levels of empathy for pain in behavioural responses. Conversely, some nurses may regard pain as a routine physiological response. With lower sensitivity to pain and higher perceived pain tolerance, they tend to exhibit weaker empathy for pain. When assessing patients’ pain, they rely more on quantifiable indicators rather than empathic understanding. This cognitive tendency can reduce their attention to patients’ subjective pain expressions, leading them to underestimate patient pain and exhibit diminished empathic responses, which may result in inadequate recognition or management of patients’ pain.5 This finding is consistent with the present study’s results, suggesting that nurses with higher perceived pain tolerance may be less sensitive to pain perception and less responsive to patients’ suffering, thereby exhibiting lower levels of empathic response in clinical pain-related situations. Therefore, nursing administrators should support nurses with low empathic responses in enhancing their sensitivity to patient pain, enabling them to more accurately recognise and comprehend patients’ suffering.

Nurses with neutral job satisfaction are more likely to be classified into the balanced response group than those with high job satisfaction. Job satisfaction reflects nurses’ overall assessment of their work environment, job responsibilities and interpersonal relationships. Nurses with high empathy for pain tend to experience greater emotional involvement, which is required to alleviate patients’ pain and provide emotional support. This process is, in essence, a form of intensive emotional labour. Previous studies have shown that nurses who bear a heavy emotional labour burden but lack adequate organisational support are more likely to experience emotional exhaustion, which may, in turn, diminish their capacity for emotional expression and empathic response.56 In addition, extended working hours, irregular shifts and disproportionate nurse–patient ratios can contribute to severe physical and mental exhaustion, resulting in elevated stress levels. Increased stress, in turn, may impair nurses’ ability to regulate emotions and process empathy effectively.57 58 Therefore, nurses with a moderate level of job satisfaction may be more likely to exhibit a stable empathy-for-pain response by maintaining a balance between emotional resonance and professional rationality, which is characteristic of the balanced response group.

sec.title: Differences in coping style scores and levels among nurses in different latent profiles
sec.p: This study identified that individuals with stronger tendencies toward negative coping were more likely to be classified into the empathy contradiction group, whereas those with weaker tendencies were more likely to be assigned to the balanced response or low empathy sensitivity groups. This suggests that nurses in the empathy contradiction group have a greater propensity to adopt negative coping styles. Nurses in this group endure significant emotional and physical distress while empathising with patients’ pain, increasing their likelihood of adopting negative coping mechanisms such as avoidance, denial or withdrawal. In line with previous research, they may attempt to alleviate distress by employing passive strategies to evade stressful or challenging situations.59 60 However, negative attitudes and emotions can detrimentally impact nurses’ physical and mental health, as negative coping styles are associated with a heightened risk of mental health disorders.61 Therefore, strengthening psychoeducational interventions and implementing targeted coping training programmes to help nurses mitigate personal distress and cultivate positive coping styles may contribute to improving the mental well-being of healthcare professionals.30

Conversely, positive coping styles are generally linked to rational and direct problem-solving.25 Nurses in the balanced response group exhibited high empathy despite experiencing moderate physical and emotional discomfort, a phenomenon that may be attributed to their extensive clinical experience, strong social support networks and promising career prospects. These factors collectively facilitated their ability to manage work-related stress. Consequently, they are more inclined to regulate their mindset and proactively seek support from others when encountering stress. Previous studies have also indicated that healthcare professionals with stronger empathy and less reliance on negative coping styles tend to possess better emotional regulation abilities and more robust social support systems, thereby enabling them to more effectively maintain emotional stability and cope with stress.50 By contrast, nurses in the low empathy sensitivity group, owing to their diminished sensitivity to patient pain, displayed lower levels of empathy. As a result, they prioritised addressing patients’ immediate pain relief needs and fulfilling clinical tasks rather than attending to patients’ psychological states. This finding is also in line with earlier studies indicating that nurses with lower levels of empathy tend to prioritise the technical and efficiency-oriented aspects of pain management, often at the expense of humanistic care during clinical interactions.5 Consequently, nurses with different empathy for pain profiles may exhibit distinct coping tendencies when dealing with work-related stress and patients’ pain needs. These findings highlight the importance of adopting a personalised approach in training nurses for pain management. Nurse managers should enhance nurses’ empathy for pain and adaptive coping abilities based on individual characteristics, thereby promoting more personalised and humanistic nursing care.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: The strength of this study lies in the inclusion of 1601 nurses from 43 hospitals in Guangdong Province, providing a robust dataset that bolsters the robustness and statistical validity of the findings. Additionally, the application of LPA facilitated a detailed understanding of nurses’ empathy for pain and enabled the identification of distinct subgroups and their unique characteristics, which is a significant advantage over traditional methods.

However, this study also has several limitations. First, the use of a convenience sampling method may have limited the representativeness of the findings. This approach was primarily selected due to practical constraints. Given the multicentre design of the study, which covered 43 healthcare institutions of various types across Guangdong Province, and considering limitations in time and human resources, convenience sampling was ultimately chosen as the most feasible and efficient strategy for data collection. Second, the study population was limited to clinical nurses in Guangdong Province, which may not fully reflect the characteristics of the national nursing workforce. To improve the generalisability of the findings, future studies should consider expanding the sampling scope when resources permit. Finally, this study adopted a cross-sectional quantitative design, which restricts the ability to infer temporal sequences and causality and limits a comprehensive understanding of the complexity and underlying mechanisms of empathy for pain. Future research should consider integrating longitudinal designs and qualitative approaches to explore its developmental trajectory and deeper psychological processes.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study employed LPA to identify three distinct latent profiles of clinical nurses’ empathy for pain: low empathy sensitivity, balanced response and empathy contradiction. Regression analyses identified perceived pain tolerance, job satisfaction and coping styles as key determinants influencing these latent profiles. These findings suggest that nursing managers should implement tailored interventions based on the characteristics and influencing factors of each latent profile, fostering the adoption of positive coping styles and enhancing empathy for pain, ultimately improving the quality of clinical pain management. Future research could incorporate qualitative or neuropsychological approaches to further explore the emotional processing and cognitive regulation mechanisms underlying empathy for pain, providing theoretical support for precision-based empathy interventions. In addition, efforts could be made to develop empathy training programmes tailored to different latent profiles and to evaluate their practicality and generalisability in real-world clinical settings, thereby fostering the development of more empathetic nursing teams.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to express their gratitude to all participants in this study, as well as to the nursing administrators at the partner hospitals, for their invaluable support in facilitating the survey.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
Prepublication history for this paper is available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2025-101039).

Data availability free text: The datasets generated and analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request. Requests should clarify the intended use of the data and will be assessed to ensure compliance with relevant ethical and confidentiality standards. Additional materials, including the study protocol and statistical analysis code, may also be made available under the same conditions.
Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.

Ethics approval: All participants provided written informed consent before enrolment, voluntarily agreed to participate and retained the right to withdraw at any time. All collected data were treated with strict confidentiality and used exclusively for this study. This study was reviewed and approved for exemption by the Ethics Review Committee of Dongguan Eighth People’s Hospital (Dongguan Children’s Hospital). The study protocol adhered to the ethical principles outlined in the Declaration of Helsinki (1964).
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.
